animalOfTheDay.name: wild dog
facts: African wild dogs vote to hunt via sneezing – more sneezes trigger departures.
They regurgitate food for pups, elders, and injured pack members.
Wild dogs have mottled coats unique to each individual.
Packs hold territories up to 900 square miles.

calendar.name: wallaby
facts: Wallabies cool by licking forearms; saliva evaporation lowers blood temperature.
Rock wallabies scale cliffs using textured soles and tail balancing.
Wallabies hop efficiently – energy use doesn't increase with speed.
They practice embryonic diapause; pausing development until environmental conditions improve.

calendar.name: walrus
facts: They are social animals and live in large herds.
Walruses are large marine mammals known for their prominent tusks.
Walruses use their tusks to haul themselves onto ice and to forage for food.
They are found in Arctic waters.

calendar.name: warthog
facts: Warthogs have facial 'warts' that protect eyes during fights.
They reverse into burrows – tusks facing outward to deter predators.
Warthogs kneel on calloused wrists to graze low vegetation.
Birds like mongooses remove ticks from warthogs during grooming sessions.

calendar.name: wasp
facts: Fig wasps co-evolved with figs – each fig species has its own wasp pollinator.
Wasps produce paper by chewing wood fibers mixed with saliva.
Parasitoid wasps lay eggs in hosts; larvae eat prey alive while avoiding vital organs.
Mud daubers build tubular nests with paralyzed spiders as living food for larvae.

calendar.name: water buffalo
facts: Wild water buffaloes are endangered; only 3,400 remain in fragmented habitats.
Domesticated for 5,000 years, they provide more milk than dairy cows in some regions.
They wallow in water to cool down and deter biting insects.
Water buffaloes have wide-splayed hooves preventing sinking in mud.

calendar.name: wild boar
facts: Wild boars have razor-sharp tusks that regrow continuously.
They create 'boar baths' – mud wallows that cool and remove parasites.
Sows build 'farrowing nests' of woven grass before giving birth.
Boars run 30 mph and jump 5-ft fences.

calendar.name: wild dog
facts: They regurgitate food for pups, elders, and injured pack members.
Wild dogs have mottled coats unique to each individual.
Packs hold territories up to 900 square miles.
African wild dogs vote to hunt via sneezing – more sneezes trigger departures.

randomAnimals.name: snail
facts: The largest land snail, the African giant snail, can grow up to 15 inches long.
Snails are hermaphrodites, meaning each individual has both male and female reproductive organs.
They have thousands of tiny teeth on their tongue-like radula, which they use to scrape food.
Snails can sleep for up to three years if the weather isn't favorable.

randomAnimals.name: yellowfin tuna
facts: They hunt in coordinated schools, herding prey toward the surface.
Yellowfin tuna can reach 50 mph – among the fastest fish.
Yellowfins maintain muscle temperature above water via specialized blood vessels.
Their fins glow yellow when excited – a display during feeding frenzies.

randomAnimals.name: sea turtle
facts: Leatherback sea turtles can dive deeper than 1,000 meters (3,280 feet).
The temperature of the nest determines the gender of the hatchlings.
They return to the same beach where they were born to lay their eggs.
Sea turtles can migrate thousands of miles between feeding and nesting grounds.
